papers.title: Most Hot Jupiters Were Cool Giant Planets for More Than 1 Gyr
papers.abstract: The origin of hot Jupiters is the oldest problem in exoplanet astrophysics. Hot Jupiters formed in situ or via disk migration should be in place just a few Myr after the formation of their host stars. On the other hand, hot Jupiters formed via eccentricity excitation and tidal damping as a result of planet--planet scattering or Kozai-Lidov oscillations may take 1 Gyr or more to arrive at their observed locations. We propose that the relative ages of hot Jupiters inside, near, and outside the bias-corrected peak of the observed hot Jupiter period distribution can be used to distinguish between these possibilities. Though the lack of precise and accurate age inferences for isolated hot Jupiter host stars makes this test difficult to implement, comparisons between the Galactic velocity dispersions of the hot Jupiter subpopulations enable this investigation. To transform relative age offsets into absolute age offsets, we calibrate the monotonically increasing solar neighborhood age--velocity dispersion relation using an all-sky sample of subgiants with precise ages and a metallicity distribution matched to that of hot Jupiter hosts. We find that the inside-peak and near-peak subpopulations are older than the outside-peak subpopulation, with the inside-peak subpopulation slightly older than the near-peak subpopulation. We conclude that at least 40\% but not more than 70\% of the hot Jupiter population must have formed via a late-time, peak-populating process like high-eccentricity migration that typically occurs more than 1.5 Gyr after system formation.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Hot Jupiters are among the most puzzling planets in our galaxy. These massive worlds orbit so close to their stars that their surfaces reach scorching temperatures of over 1,000¬∞C, completing a full orbit in just days. For over two decades, astronomers have debated how these planets ended up in such extreme locations‚Äîdid they form there, or did they migrate inward from cooler, more distant orbits? This question goes to the heart of how planetary systems evolve and helps us understand whether our own solar system, with its giant planets safely positioned far from the Sun, is typical or unusual. Solving this mystery could reveal fundamental truths about planet formation throughout the universe.

**What They Did**

Since measuring the exact ages of distant stars is notoriously difficult, the researchers devised a clever workaround using stellar motion as a cosmic clock. Just as older drivers tend to drive more cautiously while younger ones speed and weave through traffic, older stars in our galaxy move more chaotically through space due to gravitational encounters accumulated over billions of years. The team studied the motion patterns of stars hosting hot Jupiters at different orbital distances, then calibrated this relationship using stars with well-known ages. By comparing how fast these stellar systems move through space, they could determine which hot Jupiter populations are older or younger than others.

**Key Findings**

The research reveals that most hot Jupiters didn't start where we find them today. At least 40% to 70% of these planets began as "cool giants" orbiting far from their stars for over a billion years before spiraling inward. The planets closest to their stars are actually the oldest, suggesting they've had more time to complete their inward journey. This pattern strongly supports the idea that gravitational battles between planets or interactions with distant companion stars gradually push these worlds into their current hellish orbits over vast timescales.

**Looking Forward**

This discovery reshapes our understanding of planetary system evolution, suggesting that the architecture we observe today often results from billions of years of dynamic changes rather than the original formation process. As upcoming space missions discover thousands more exoplanets, astronomers can now better interpret these findings within the context of long-term planetary migration, bringing us closer to understanding how common stable systems like our own might be.

papers.title: A Theory of transmission spectroscopy of planetary winds: Spectral-line saturation and limits on mass-loss inference
papers.abstract: Transmission spectroscopy is a key technique in the characterization of exoplanet atmospheres and has been widely applied to planets undergoing hydrodynamic escape. While a robust analytic theory exists for transmission spectra of hydrostatic atmospheres, the corresponding interpretation for escaping atmospheres has so far relied on numerical modeling. In this work, we develop a theory of transmission spectroscopy in hydrodynamically escaping atmospheres by coupling the standard transmission geometry to a steady-state, spherically symmetric, isothermal outflow. This approach yields closed-form expressions and allows the optical depth inversion problem to be examined. The analytic solution reveals that transmission spectroscopy of planetary winds naturally separates into two regimes. In an opacity-limited regime, transmission depths retain sensitivity to the atmospheric mass-loss rate. Beyond a critical threshold, however, spectral-line cores become saturated and no longer provide a unique constraint on the mass flux. This transition is marked by a sharp analytic boundary of the form œÉ(Œª)√ó M C_(sat), where C_(sat) is a constant set by the thermodynamic and geometric properties of the wind. This condition specifies when the inversion between transmission depth and mass-loss rate admits a real solution. Once it is violated, the effective transit radius is no longer controlled by opacity or mass loss, but by the geometric extent of the absorbing wind. These results demonstrate that spectral-line saturation in transmission spectroscopy corresponds to a fundamental loss of invertibility between absorption and atmospheric mass loss, rather than a gradual weakening of sensitivity. The theory provides a physically transparent explanation for why strong transmission line cores often fail to constrain mass-loss rates, while weaker lines and line wings remain diagnostic.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to understand a distant world by studying the light that passes through its atmosphere as it crosses in front of its star. This technique, called transmission spectroscopy, has become our most powerful tool for learning what exoplanet atmospheres are made of and how they behave. Some planets are so hot that their atmospheres are literally boiling away into space‚Äîa dramatic process that could determine whether these worlds can retain any atmosphere at all. Understanding how much atmosphere these planets are losing is crucial for predicting their fate and finding worlds that might harbor life. Until now, scientists have struggled to accurately measure these atmospheric escape rates, often getting confusing or contradictory results from their observations.

**What They Did**

The researchers developed a mathematical theory to explain how light behaves when it passes through an atmosphere that's actively escaping into space. Think of it like trying to see through steam rising from a boiling pot‚Äîthe moving gas affects how light travels through it. Previous studies relied on complex computer simulations to interpret these observations, but this team created simple equations that describe the physics directly. They modeled the escaping atmosphere as a steady wind flowing outward from the planet, then calculated how this wind would absorb starlight at different wavelengths. This approach allowed them to derive clear, mathematical relationships between what telescopes observe and the actual rate at which the planet loses its atmosphere.

**Key Findings**

The team discovered that atmospheric measurements fall into two distinct categories, separated by a sharp boundary. When atmospheric escape is moderate, telescopes can accurately measure how fast the planet is losing gas. But beyond a critical threshold, the absorption lines become "saturated"‚Äîlike trying to see through fog so thick that adding more fog doesn't make it any more opaque. At this point, the observations no longer reveal the escape rate but instead just show the physical size of the escaping gas cloud. This explains why astronomers sometimes get reliable measurements from faint spectral features while stronger signals paradoxically provide no useful information about mass loss.

**Looking Forward**

This breakthrough provides astronomers with a roadmap for interpreting their observations more accurately. Instead of being puzzled by strong but uninformative signals, researchers now know to focus on weaker spectral lines that still retain sensitivity to atmospheric escape rates. This will lead to better estimates of how quickly exoplanets lose their atmospheres, helping us understand which worlds can maintain stable atmospheres over billions of years‚Äîa key factor in the search for potentially habitable planets.

papers.title: Closed-Form Statistical Relations Between Projected Separation, Semimajor Axis, Companion Mass, and Host Acceleration
papers.abstract: I derive the statistical relationship between a radial velocity or astrometric acceleration (a trend), a companion's mass, and the projected separation of the companion. These relationships, expressed as probability density functions, are analytic and independent of all Keplerian orbital elements so long as orbits are randomly oriented in space. I also derive a closed-form expression for the probability distribution of the ratio of the projected separation to the semimajor axis at fixed eccentricity. This expression can be numerically integrated over eccentricity for an arbitrary distribution of eccentricities. I verify my results with empirical comparisons to equivalent but more complex expressions in the literature based on the equations of Keplerian orbits. The closed-formed expressions derived here would be especially useful for any calculation that requires derivatives, e.g., Hamiltonian Monte Carlo. I also provide a Jupyter notebook including all figures and calculations.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to study a distant lighthouse by watching how its beam affects nearby boats‚Äîthis is essentially how astronomers hunt for planets around other stars. When we can't see these "exoplanets" directly, we detect them by observing how their gravity tugs on their host stars, causing subtle wobbles or gradual shifts in the star's motion. However, translating these tiny movements into useful information about the planet‚Äîlike its mass, distance from the star, and orbital path‚Äîrequires complex mathematical relationships. This research provides astronomers with a powerful new toolkit: simplified equations that make it much faster and easier to extract crucial details about distant worlds from the signals we observe.

**What They Did**

The researcher developed mathematical shortcuts for connecting the dots between what telescopes can measure and what astronomers want to know about exoplanets. Think of it like creating a universal translator between two languages: the language of stellar wobbles (what we observe) and the language of planetary properties (what we want to understand). Instead of using complicated, multi-step calculations that astronomers have relied on for decades, this work produced clean, direct formulas. The researcher also created computer simulations to double-check that these new equations give the same answers as the traditional methods, ensuring the shortcuts don't sacrifice accuracy for convenience.

**Key Findings**

The new equations work regardless of how a planet's orbit is tilted relative to Earth, making them universally applicable to exoplanet discoveries. Most importantly, these formulas are "closed-form," meaning they give direct answers without requiring computers to crunch through multiple iterative steps. The researcher verified that these simplified equations produce identical results to existing methods while being significantly more efficient to calculate.

**Looking Forward**

This mathematical toolkit will accelerate exoplanet research by making data analysis faster and more efficient. The streamlined calculations are particularly valuable for advanced statistical methods that require thousands of repetitive computations, potentially helping astronomers characterize exoplanets more quickly and discover subtle patterns in planetary systems across our galaxy.

papers.title: ExoMiner++ 2.0: Vetting TESS Full-Frame Image Transit Signals
papers.abstract: The Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) Full-Frame Images (FFIs) provide photometric time series for millions of stars, enabling transit searches beyond the limited set of pre-selected 2-minute targets. However, FFIs present additional challenges for transit identification and vetting. In this work, we apply ExoMiner++ 2.0, an adaptation of the ExoMiner++ framework originally developed for TESS 2-minute data, to FFI light curves. The model is used to perform large-scale planet versus non-planet classification of Threshold Crossing Events across the sectors analyzed in this study. We construct a uniform vetting catalog of all evaluated signals and assess model performance under different observing conditions. We find that ExoMiner++ 2.0 generalizes effectively to the FFI domain, providing robust discrimination between planetary signals, astrophysical false positives, and instrumental artifacts despite the limitations inherent to longer cadence data. This work extends the applicability of ExoMiner++ to the full TESS dataset and supports future population studies and follow-up prioritization.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to spot a firefly blinking in front of a distant streetlight‚Äîthat's essentially what astronomers do when hunting for planets around other stars. When a planet crosses in front of its star, it creates a tiny dip in brightness that space telescopes can detect. NASA's TESS (Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite) has revolutionized this cosmic game of hide-and-seek by monitoring hundreds of thousands of stars simultaneously. However, buried within TESS's treasure trove of data are millions more stars that could harbor planets‚Äîwe just needed better tools to sift through all that information. This research matters because it dramatically expands our ability to find new worlds, bringing us closer to answering one of humanity's most profound questions: How common are planets like Earth?

**What They Did**

The researchers upgraded an artificial intelligence system called ExoMiner++ to work like a highly trained detective specializing in planet detection. Think of it as teaching a computer to distinguish between genuine planet signals and imposters‚Äîthings like double stars, instrument glitches, or other cosmic phenomena that can masquerade as planets. The original ExoMiner++ was designed to analyze TESS's highest-quality data, taken every two minutes for specially selected stars. The new version, ExoMiner++ 2.0, learned to work with lower-quality data captured every 30 minutes for millions of additional stars. Like training a detective to solve cases with grainier security footage, this required teaching the AI to recognize planetary signatures even in noisier, less detailed observations.

**Key Findings**

The upgraded AI system proved remarkably adaptable, successfully distinguishing real planet candidates from false alarms even when working with the more challenging 30-minute data. ExoMiner++ 2.0 maintained its detective skills across different observing conditions, reliably identifying which signals deserved further investigation and which could be dismissed as false positives. The system created a comprehensive catalog of vetted signals, essentially building a reliable database of potential planet discoveries from previously untapped TESS observations.

**Looking Forward**

This breakthrough means astronomers can now mine the full TESS dataset for planets, potentially discovering thousands of new worlds that were previously hidden in unanalyzed data. These discoveries will fuel future studies of planetary populations and help prioritize which candidates deserve follow-up observations with other telescopes, accelerating our understanding of how planetary systems form and evolve throughout the universe.

papers.title: A nomenclature for individual exocomets
papers.abstract: With recent observational advancements, exocomet studies have entered a new era: we have moved from an epoch where exocomets' signatures were analysed to identify their true nature to a new epoch where individual exocomets' detections are studied in detail to characterise the observed bodies. In this context, as with other astronomical objects such as exoplanets and minor bodies in the solar system, a nomenclature system is needed to uniquely identify any observed exocometary body. Here, after outlining the purpose of a nomenclature and its required characteristics, we review the information on exocomets that can be included in the nomenclature. Finally, we propose an exocomet nomenclature scheme to identify the individual exocomets that have been discovered or yet to be discovered. Examples of nomenclature names of a few archetypal exocomets are provided.
papers.summary:
# Scientists Create the First "Phone Book" for Comets Beyond Our Solar System

**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to organize your contacts without names‚Äîjust descriptions like "tall person from coffee shop" or "friend with red car." That's essentially the problem astronomers have been facing with exocomets, the icy cosmic wanderers orbiting stars beyond our Sun. As our telescopes become more powerful, we're not just spotting these distant comets anymore‚Äîwe're studying them individually, tracking their unique behaviors and characteristics. Without a proper naming system, it's like trying to manage a growing library where every book is simply called "that story about the detective." This research matters because it establishes the foundation for organizing and understanding an entirely new category of cosmic objects that could tell us how planetary systems form and evolve.

**What They Did**

The researchers didn't point telescopes at the sky or crunch observational data. Instead, they tackled a more fundamental challenge: creating a systematic way to name individual exocomets. Think of it like developing the rules for street addresses in a rapidly expanding city. They examined what information we can gather about each exocomet‚Äîsuch as which star it orbits, when it was discovered, and its observable characteristics. Then they designed a naming scheme that would work not just for the handful of exocomets we know today, but for the thousands we expect to discover in the coming decades.

**Key Findings**

The team successfully developed a comprehensive naming system that can accommodate the unique properties of exocomets while remaining practical for astronomers to use. They demonstrated their system by applying it to several well-studied exocomets, showing how each would receive a distinct identifier. While the paper doesn't provide specific numbers of exocomets catalogued, it represents the first standardized approach to organizing these distant objects, much like how we systematically name hurricanes or catalog asteroids in our own solar system.

**Looking Forward**

This naming system arrives at a pivotal moment in exoplanet science. As next-generation telescopes come online, we'll likely discover exocomets by the hundreds or thousands. Having a standardized naming system means astronomers worldwide can communicate clearly about specific objects, track their behavior over time, and build comprehensive databases. This could accelerate our understanding of how comets‚Äîwhich are essentially frozen time capsules from the early solar system‚Äîreveal the history and composition of distant planetary systems, potentially bringing us closer to understanding how common Earth-like worlds might be.
